author: Randy Chung
title: M-Pesa payment rails integration
description: M-Pesa is the most successful mobile-phone financial service in the developing world. Integrating with them will make Ada more accessible.

assessments.note: The proposal addresses a challenge that is close to the ambitions of Cardano in the African continent but I provided this score because it does not elaborate on how it will effectively achieve this. The mere mention of an API connecting M-Pesa and Cardano seems inefficient for such a proposal that has a tremendous upside to countries and a lot of people if the challenge is met. I would like to see more details provided. At this stage, I am leaning more towards a lower score but have rated it in the middle in the hope that further details can be provided to improve my assessment and confidence.

The problem statement doesn't present a problem, but rather a statement that M-PESA is the most successful mobile-phone financial service in the developing world, but no information has been provided to support this statement.

There is not enough information to understand how the proposal will address the challenge. It is only suggesting an integration of the ADA with the M-PESA through an API, but this is extremely vague.
Not too bad of an idea to meet the challenge, but he other aspects of the proposal are minimal and inadequate

Concept is great - bringing interoperability/integration that can help bridge gap and eliminate friction points are always useful. However, there isn't enough depth in this proposal that would help us navigate how it can actually come to life.
This proposal identifies an easily convertible group of individuals who are already familiar with digital money. the group is in need and is large in quantity.
It seems to me that M-Pesa is an existing service and it will more helpful if the proposal explained what API is.

The proposal lacks any development plans including itemised listing of resources against the requested budget. There are no milestones or timelines presented. There's also no examples of previous achievements or familiarity with this type of development.

There is no description of a plan. There is only mention of a team with skills in software development and business development, but there are no details of how many these people are and who these people are. The proposer did not detail his professional experience / skills. Without this information there is no indication of success in the implementation.

No real evidence of their claims: "Our team consists of professionals in software development and business development, with existing ties to M-Pesa's use in Kenya" Anyone can say that. No links no plan not nothing

There is no ability to validate claims and verify the experience listed. There isn't any professional link, website that would help us navigate that, maybe linked in profile, past work, etc. It would help determine credibility a great deal. Proposal also is lacking some basic understanding of budgetary requirements beyond stating one grand figure. There isn't any break down of items, nor how these amounts help us achieve the desired target. This is primarily due to the fact there there isn't sensible plan presented beyond concept stage just yet.
While the idea is great, the description of skills only consists of one line. the proposal would receive greater marks by revealing who the team consists of.

The proposal has an overall objective which is to build an integration but it didn't explain more specifically how it can be built and what connection/engagement it has already established with M-Pesa.
proposal is fairly light on the finer details like deliverables, contracts, scope, core business relationships

Aside from the mention of what is required to meet the challenge, i.e. an API between M-Pesa and Cardano, this proposal does not provide enough information to make its goals feasible in my assessment. It does not clearly define the available resources that will be devoted to the project, how they will be used and the stages of the development. There is mention of 'existing ties to M-Pesa's use' but does not elaborate on these ties. Is it with the developers M-Pesa or is it ties with users of M-Pesa? At this stage, it seems a great idea/proposal but more details will need to be provided in order to proceed to the next stage.
The proposal is a draft, there is no detail to check the feasibility and understand how the challenge will be addressed. I recommend details description according to the Catalyst guidelines.

No bios, no breakdown of funds no technical approach, no explanation of what it would do, how it would work with m-pesa. The telecoms are fiercely protective of their fachises. I worked with three of them in Afghanistan for 12 years. Not a bunch that opens up to third parties easily.

Due to the fact that this is very incomplete proposal - just an idea - there isn't anything we can actually work on that would help us navigate this better. Lack of basic elements such as roadmap, milestones, nor is there any definition of success and how to measure it. It also is missing elements that would touch upon any challenges/risks that authors are considering. Adding all of those things into proposal would make it more investable. But not in the present stage.
the proposal fails to identify key performance indicators or a clear goal on how many new cardano users would be brought into the ecosystem.

•	There is no roadmap or milestones to specify step by step plan. The objective is too board and it didn't explain how to assess success. There is no breakdown or clear demonstration to explain how the funding will be used.

solution: We plan to build an integration with the API that M-Pesa provides to make it easier to transact using Ada.
experience: Our team consists of professionals in software development and business development, with existing ties to M-Pesa's use in Kenya
